right uh because serverless has kind of become this this buzzword lately well not lately it's been around for a couple
years now but uh I've kind of found anytime something becomes a buzzword it starts losing its meaning people kind of
start saying it all the time but uh when I first heard about server list I was
like what that doesn't make any sense because we know as developers our code needs a
server to run our code has to run on a server it needs a CPU it needs memory
but with server less you're telling me that there's no server and that doesn't really make sense so for me what I found
a better way to think about server lists is not just not that there's no server but rather that there's less server uh
there's less server for us to have to maintain and manage there's uh less server running in the cloud that we have
to pay for at the end of the month uh so with serverless yes our code still runs on a server it's not this magic thing
that defies physics where all of a sudden our code can run without a CPU uh it's just that we're using less server
and we as a benefit have to manage less server as well but let's go way back uh
if we go way back to the time before Cloud existed you know everything was on premise and you know I I started my
career only about 15 years ago so I don't think I'm that old but when I started out there was no Cloud
everything was on premise every company that I worked at had massive data centers and it was it was a pain in the
butt to do anything because if you just wanted to create an app well the first thing you had to do was get the team
together and figure out how much server you needed and then once you figured out how many users you expect then you'd
place an order server would arrive on my desk six to eight weeks later I'd have to take that down to the data center
rack and stack it cable it up and then had have to work with like the system administration team to get the operating
system installed and up to date I'd have to work with the security team to get it all locked down so we could put it online uh the networking team would have
to install like the DNS and all the routing tables and all that stuff and it was just a pain in the butt and
fortunately around that time Amazon kind of looked around and said hey you know we've got a ton of servers because
amazon.com and if we look at it not all these servers are running at 100% capacity there's a lot of idle CPU
cycles that are being essentially wasted they said what if we allowed people to essentially rent space on our servers
and with that they came up with this concept that I like to call Cloud infrastructure where the first iteration
of cloud was I could go to AWS and say hey I need a virtual machine and I want
a four core CPU 16 gigs of RAM and now with a couple clicks of the mouse I can
have a server up and running for me in the cloud I didn't have to wait eight weeks for it to arrive at my desk uh we
didn't have to worry about do we buy a big enough server ahead of time like what's our scaling going to be uh
because all that was managed for us in the cloud but yes this is great but I'm
still managing this server so I still have to have my system administrators install the latest version of Windows
have to keep up to date with the security patches I got to make sure my security team's locking down the networking and I've got to do all the
routing and DNS stuff myself so way more convenient than having to buy your own server way more convenient than having
to rack and stack yourself with Cloud infrastructure you know we're still managing servers and the next iteration
came about and this is what I like to call Cloud platform so this is something like with elastic beanock I know not I
no longer have to worry about an operating system I can just say hey to AWS I've got an asp.net core web app
that I want to run in the cloud I can rightclick publish I tell AWS that yeah I want to rent out a four core CPU 16
gigs of RAM and it's as easy as that I don't have to worry about the operating system AWS takes care of the security
patches takes care of the routing and the DNS stuff for me so life got a lot easier with Cloud platforms like elastic
beanock but the problem is at the end of the month you still get a bill because
you're renting space in their data center so you're telling Amazon telling AWS I need four core CPU and 16 gigs of
RAM and they go sure and just like how you know I'm here right now in Sydney I'm from California but I still got to
pay rent at the end of the month to my landlord whether I'm there or not same is true with Cloud platforms like elastic beanock so whether your users
use your app or not whether they're only awake during the day and they're all asleep at night and nobody's using it
you still get a bill at the end of the month because you've told adbs I need four core CPU 16 gigs of RAM so finally
we get to the the final iteration where we introduce serverless and with
serverless same concept as uh the cloud platforms where we don't have to worry about operating systems we don't have to
worry about security patches we don't have to worry about networking we can just focus on our code and Publishing it to the cloud but the really cool thing
with serverless is now I don't even tell AWS how much I need I don't even have to tell them that I want this many CPU
cores and this much RAM because they're going to take care of that for me so with serverless if I have let's say my
app goes viral right I get a million downloads it' be an incredible day and
that's okay because ads will scale up my serverless instance to handle that load and likewise when all my users are
asleep in the middle of the night they scale it all the way down to zero so that I don't have to pay for it when I'm
not using it so serverless we're able to vastly reduce our monthly bill and the
best news is it'll still scale up and down to handle whatever demand and users we our users might have so so why do I
love serverless well tracks away the servers because again I'm the only developer working on my mobile apps I'm
the only developer thus working on the backends and I don't want to have to manage operating systems I don't want to have to install security patches and
with serverless all that's done for me I don't have to worry about any of this stuff instant scale so if again my app
goes viral ads will scale up to handle that load and then when all my users go to bed it scales down to zero which
means I don't get a massive build at the end of the month because I only have to pay for what I use now this is where we
start getting into the nitty gritt and some caveats because yes it's great that
AWS spins down my instances to zero if nobody's using it because it'll lower our bill at the end of the month but it
introduces this concept of a cold start and so if you think about it this does make sense like if nobody's using my app
ads scales all the instances down to zero nothing's actually running in the cloud my codee's still kind of there uh
the event triggers are listening waiting for that next HTTP request and when they get it they're going to wake up so let's
say you wake up at 6: am you're the first person to launch my app well you're going to hit what's called a cold
start because when that HTP request happens when that trigger wakes up my code well AWS has to quickly allocate uh
some CPU some memory and then net also has to spin up and run my app so uh with
net 6 this used to be more of a bigger deal uh we would we were seeing cold start times of about a second um but you
know I will say even with that I've been using L for my back end for years my apps still thankfully have festar
reviews I've never gotten complaints um so for mobile users we're pretty flexible we're kind of used to like poor
internet connections like you know conference Wi-Fi or we're on the bus and we're switching cell towers so uh mobile
users are a little bit more forgiving and they never even mentioned never noticed that one second cold start uh
delay but now with down at 7 down at 8 thanks to aot we're seeing cold starts
drop down to about 300 400 milliseconds and to me this is completely negligible
like literally the blink your to blink your eyes takes about 300 millisecs so
if uh some of my users get a cold start penalty of 300 400 milliseconds I don't
even care they probably won't even notice uh but the good news is uh we have the data that show that the
majority of your users about 70 to 80% of your users will uh hit what's called a War start and that's because you know
let's say you woke up at 6: a.m. you launch app first you get this 300 millisecond cold start penalty but then
I like to sleep in a little bit so I wake up at 6:05 launch the app well that instance is already up and running so I
experienced this warm start which now we're talking 9 10 milliseconds whatever no big deal um so the way this works is
yes the first user to trigger your serverless back end will experience this cold start but ads keeps that uh that
server instance up and running for about 15 minutes so until it's idle for about 15 minutes they won't scale it back down
to zero just in case another user comes along so again the good news is the majority of your users will hit what we
call a warm start but it is something important something to keep in mind uh because it may impact your business now
it's tough nowadays to think of examples but let's say you work in finance you got to make uh stock trades right so
that stock trade doesn't happen right away then your company could lose millions of dollars well yeah that 300
millisecond cold start could be pretty bad but I'd argue probably 90 95% of apps users will never
notice a 300 millisecond co cold start delay now I do want to highlight you'll
see the numbers drop massively right here and this was because in donet 7 the
uh the team at Microsoft introduced something called native aot aot stands for ahead of time
compilation and this is one of the ways we're seeing we're able to get this IC
decrease in cold start times because if you've never heard of this before uh you might be thinking well wait a minute you
know every time I write code in C I've got to compile it so my codee's always compiled ahead of time anyways right
well what actually has always happened since the history of.net was when you click compile and that dll is created uh
your code actually just goes down to What's called the Microsoft Intermediate Language the compiler doesn't actually
generate assembly level ones and zeros like the code that actually goes through the process it creates uh msil and then it's not
until your app runs at and when it launches theet runtime looks and sees okay what CPU are you running on okay
well now I'll quickly compile that code into assembly level into into ones and
zeros for that specific processor and so with Native aot we're now able to tell
net ahead of time hey you know what go ahead and just compile it all the way down you let's skip this whole
intermediate layer and just compile it down to assembly level down to ones and zeros and with that now our cold starts
get down to 400 300 milliseconds because net doesn't have to essentially just in
time compile based on our CPU architecture that it finds running on the server something also really cool in
donet 8 they added these uh properties we can add to our CSR file so if you
right click edit your CS Pro you can add um you can specify an optimization preference for native
so you can tell the compiler hey I want to I want to optimize size or I want to optimize speed and the compiler if you
say size we'll try to look to see like hey is there any code that yeah these files exist but I don't think you
they're actually touching this code so we can remove that so it'll uh if you optimize for size it'll make that dll a
little bit smaller and if you tell it optimize for Speed then of course it's going to look for little ways to
optimize the code we wrote to make it a little bit faster and the introduce this ilc
instruction instruction set property so again in your CS Pro File you can add ilc instruction set and if you know the
server you're running on like for example if I know I'm pushing my code to
um 8s Lambda and I'm running on x86 I can specify the skylike processor which
is that's the instruction set that Intel uses and it'll optimize our code even further because whether you know it or
not the reason CPUs are different is because they have different instructions sets and so some CPUs can do things that
other CPUs can't and again if we can specify that in our CS PR file now net
can optimize our code even further so our app will be a little bit faster so again something to keep in mind but
nowadays with donet 7 donet 8 thanks to Native aot we're seeing cold starts dropping down to about 300 400
milliseconds does that really matter ah probably not unless you're in that

database well you can have a database trigger wake up and maybe we send that user a welcome email where and the thing
I love about this is before this scenario really existed we always had to
do like batch jobs right like there'd be that overnight Cron job you'd run that would maybe clean up the database or
maybe once an hour you'd have have some code run well now we can have these
events run as soon as something happens and kind of get that response to the users better user experience and
